Package enamel

Class TactilePlayer

  • java.lang.Object
    • enamel.Player
      • enamel.TactilePlayer
  • public class TactilePlayer
extends Player
    This class controls the hardware for a Raspberry Pi with physical Braille cells (Using "Metec B11 Braille Cell") and programmable buttons, using the Pi4J library.

    The constructor initializes the GPIO (general purpose in/out) pins and takes as arguments the number of Braille Cells and the number of buttons the system should use. This class also contains several methods that allow for the manipulation of the physical braille cell. Currently, due to the way the GPIO pins are numbered, the buttons must be specifically placed on the GPIO pins. See the Raspberry Pi GPIO pin diagram, found online, for more information on how the pins are numbered. Currently, the GPIO pins 4, 5, 6, 7 are connected to physical push buttons. New buttons could be added, but either they must be placed in GPIO pins 8, 9... etc. (in sequence) or the way the buttonList is created must be changed. The individual Braille Cells can be accessed using the getCell(int) method and the cell's index. Similarly, the buttons can be accessed using the getButton(int) method, and they are indexed from left to right. Both of these methods return the actual reference of the objects, meaning you can then call methods from each of the object's respective classes to manipulate them. You can use the getButton(int) method to get the reference of a specific button.

    Author:
    ENAMEL team: Sunjik Lee, Li Yin, Vassilios Tzerpos.

      TactilePlayer​(int brailleCellNumber, int buttonNumber)
      Initializes the GPIO pins for the single Metec B11 braille cell, whose pins are specified in the fields ON, DOUT, STROBE, and CLOCK.

    • Constructor Detail

      • TactilePlayer

        public TactilePlayer​(int brailleCellNumber,
                     int buttonNumber)
              throws java.lang.SecurityException,
                     java.io.IOException
        Initializes the GPIO pins for the single Metec B11 braille cell, whose pins are specified in the fields ON, DOUT, STROBE, and CLOCK. The two parameters brailleCellNumber and buttonNumber should not exceed 1 and 4, respectively, until future modifications to the code and the hardware are completed. Due to the limitations of the Raspberry Pi (specifically, that it has limited GPIO pins), this number will be limited.
        Parameters:
        brailleCellNumber - the number of braille cells the TactilePlayer should have
        buttonNumber - the number of buttons the TactilePlayer should have
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        java.lang.SecurityException
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if one or both of the two parameters is negative or 0, or if brailleCellNumber exceeds 1, or if buttonNumber exceeds 4.

    • Method Detail

      • getButton

        public com.pi4j.io.gpio.GpioPinDigitalInput getButton​(int index)
        Returns a reference to the button at the index passed as argument. The main purpose of providing this method is so the client can add actionListeners to the button. Buttons are numbered from left to right, from 0 to (buttonNumber-1), buttonNumber being the number of buttons initialized by the constructor.
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the button to be returned
        Returns:
        reference to the GpioPinDigitalInput object at the index passed as argument
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the index is negative or equal to or bigger than buttonNumber (the number of buttons initialized)

      • refresh

        public void refresh()
        Refreshes the Metec B11 braille cell to match the current state of the instantiated BrailleCell object. For the TactilePlayer class, this method calls a method of the GPIO library. low() turns off the GPIO pin, high() turns on the GPIO pin. To access all the pins on the braille cell, first, the STROBE must be turned off. Then, for each pin (for one braille cell, 8 pins, two braille cells, 16), this method turns off the CLOCK, turns on/off the DOUT to match the BrailleCell object's current pin(matching in reverse order), then turns on the CLOCK again. At the end of the loop, the STROBE must be turned back on, at which point the braille cell will display the pins.
        Specified by:
        refresh in class Player

      • addSkipButtonListener

        public void addSkipButtonListener​(int index,
                                  java.lang.String param,
                                  ScenarioParser sp)
        Adds a Listener (which listens for GPIO pin interrupts) with the specified index passed as argument. The index must be between 0 and buttonNumber.

        The GPIO listener requires a parameter from the ScenarioParser class, needed for it to call ScenarioParser.skip() method as well as have access to the userInput field. Pressing this button will skip to the specified area in the scenario file.

        Specified by:
        addSkipButtonListener in class Player
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the Listener to be added
        param - the String in ScenarioParser to skip to, needed for ScenarioParser's skip(String indicator) method
        sp - the reference to the current ScenarioParser object

      • addRepeatButtonListener

        public void addRepeatButtonListener​(int index,
                                    ScenarioParser sp)
        Adds a Listener (which listens for GPIO pin interrupts) with the specified index passed as argument. The index must be between 0 and buttonNumber.

        The GPIO listener requires a parameter from the ScenarioParser class, needed for it to call ScenarioParser.repeatText() method. Pressing this button will repeat the specified text in the scenario file.

        Specified by:
        addRepeatButtonListener in class Player
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the Listener to be added
        sp - the reference to the current ScenarioParser object

      • removeButtonListener

        public void removeButtonListener​(int index)
        Removes the Listener from the index of buttonList passed as argument. The index must be between 0 and buttonNumber.
        Specified by:
        removeButtonListener in class Player
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the Listener to be removed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the index is negative or equal to or bigger than buttonNumber (the number of buttons initialized)
